–ò–ú–•–û.

"Find Out the Impact of Your Past Projects

Many resumes list out responsibilities, but they don‚Äôt mention impact or specifics. They might say ‚ÄúBuilt and shipped the website rewrite for MyCompany‚Äù, but they don‚Äôt talk about how many people viewed the website, how much incremental revenue it generated, by what percentage did the loading times improve, by what percentage did the codebase shrink, and so on. In many cases, this is because the person writing the resume is also unaware of the actual impact.
So find it out. For your current position, ask around on your team and through your manager. What is the expected impact of the project? Or what was the impact of the launch? For past positions, reach out to your old team or previous managers and ask about the impact. They might have better pointers on what this was.

Finally, if you don‚Äôt have an exact impact, estimate to a good approximation. Can you give a rough percentage on the improvement made? A rough estimate on from what number to what number things changed? With impact, you don‚Äôt need to be exact. ‚ÄúClose enough‚Äù is better than nothing."

Hello. If I were an HR manager, I‚Äòd say your CV looks pretty good (perfect summary, wide range of technical skills, well-structured experience described with action verbs, all those impacts/numbers you provided in bold.) 
As a linguist, I‚Äòd say you use too much ‚Äûfluff‚Äú, i.e. unnecessary vanity words, which distract. Your results speak for themselves. In my opinion, you don‚Äòt have to praise yourself by saying how cool you are (e.g. ‚Äûplayed a pivotal role; comprehensive review; robust monitoring system‚Äú, etc.) Would you deploy a non-robust system? If not, I think it‚Äòs safe to drop the word. 
One more thing about the language - ‚Äûsuccessfully delivering a recipe scaling tool‚Äú while working for a biopharmaceutical company. Could it be that you mean ‚Äûmedical prescriptions‚Äú, not ‚Äûrecipes‚Äú?
As for the contents of what you have written, a hiring senior manager might have some questions for you regarding:
- ‚Äûintegration of new microservices‚Ä¶resulting in improved performance‚Äú. This is a very questionable statement, because microservices are based on remote procedure calls that have significant performance penalties. Maybe what you improved was scalability, but that‚Äòs a different metric.
- ‚Äûdesigned and implemented new features in the existing system, creating a streamlined architecture, PoC models‚Ä¶‚Äú - These are completely different things mentioned in one sentence. When you implement new features and extend existing system, you don‚Äòt create an architecture, you work within an existing architecture. If you rework the architecture, it‚Äòs not about features.
- ‚Äûincreased user satisfaction to 90%‚Äú. If you really measured user satisfaction, then you could quote how you did it. Was it NPS score? What was NPS score before and what was it after?
- ‚ÄûLed a cross-functional team of 15-25 developers‚Äú. Sounds like you are not sure how many people were in your team. Do you mean that you grew your team from 15 to 25 people?
- If you are interviewing for a team lead position, it‚Äòs always good to show how you, as a team leader, built your team, grew it and developed people in your team, helped them grow from juniors to seniors. You should demonstrate relevant experience, showing your ability to work not only with technologies but also with people. 
Sorry for so many words. I hope I was able to help. Good luck!
